captions.text: (TurboPunch Logo)
Hey you!
My name is Thomas ’TomSka' Ridgewell and I’ve been making videos on the Internet for over 12 years...
URGH! That’s a really long time.
(12 Years of Videos)

Now while the best way to succeed at something
is to enjoy doing it and do it a lot it never
hurts to get some free advice.

So, if you’re hoping to make videos on these
here Internets then here’s everything I

think you need to know to get started and
not... Die.
*Takes a deep breath*
PART ONE! WATCH AND LEARN...
AND STEAL!

We are what we eat and everything we make
is the result of everything that has inspired

us so before diving into the world of stuff-making
you need to watch a lot of stuff.

Discover what excites and inspires you and
let it shape you as a creative. The more you

consume, the sooner you’ll develop the big
mess known as "your own style".

Foot note! It’s also important that you
don’t just watch good stuff.

"Those who cannot remember the past are condemned
to repeat it" so watch poorly made and unsuccessful

content and try to understand why it didn't
work. Learn from other people’s mistakes.
PART TWO! WHO ARE YOU?!

Now the question of who you want to be and
what you want to do is entirely up to you.

Makeup, music, vlogging, gaming, reviews,
news, how to’s, comedy, cartoons, film making,
baking, fun facts, visual effects or... Sex?

No! Not sex! That's bad... Illegal probably...
You're 12.

But before you can even begin making and uploading
videos you need a name for yourself. "A brand"
if you want to talk like a douche.
Sadly the Internet has been around long enough though that almost every possible username
you could come up with has already been taken...
Including your own name... Jim Stevens.
(Jim) Oh, what? That sucks man... Come on...

Try making a list of your favourite words
and things and smash them together until you

hopefully find something unique and not stolen
by someone else already...

However! It’s still not that simple. A good
username needs to be memorable and easy to

share. So before you go rushing to register
your new username on every website imaginable

you need to make sure it makes sense to more
than just you.
I personally recommend ’The IRL Test’.
Which is basically where If you can tell your username to someone in real life and more often than not they can

write it down correctly then it’s probably
good enough...

Foot note! Don’t put numbers in your username
you stupid fu-
PART THREE! SECONDARY CHANNEL!!
Going from zero to hero...
Why would I say that?

...Means trying a lot of new things and you’re
not necessarily going to want everything you
make to be a representation of you and your "brand".

That’s why it’s a good idea to have a
secondary YouTube channel. Somewhere to post
updates, try new things and make mistakes on...
So many mistakes...
(Canadians on a Plane)
PART FOUR! GETTING STARTED!!

Getting started and making your first videos
can be scary...
But I think it’s important that you hear this...

You suck. You do. You’re awful and you’re
going to be awful for a long time.
(Baby Crying) Oh, no, stop crying. Oh come on! NO!

You see, you don’t get good until you’ve
made something that’s kind of okay; and

you don’t make something that’s kind of
okay until you’ve made a lot of things that really suck.
What i'm trying to say is that you shouldn’t be afraid or held back by your own suckiness.

Embrace it; challenge it; prove it wrong;
and above all never give up.
(American National Anthem)

Warm fuzzy feelings aside, though, you’re
going to need some equipment. It’s pointless
for me to recommend a good camera or microphone as technology is constantly evolving but I can tell you this:

1) Sound is more important than visuals. Peoples
ears are a lot more easily offended than their

eyes so consider getting a good microphone
first and foremost.
Hey! (Mouth noises)

2) You don’t need to bankrupt yourself to
get started. If you’ve got what it takes
you’ll be able to afford better equipment over time.

3) Creativity is kind of like cooking. I know
it sounds stupid but bear with me.
(Bear growl)

Before you complain that
you don’t have the friends or the resources

to get started; look around at the ingredients
you have available to you. Everything from

your friends and family’s places of work
to the objects laying around your house can

be used to create something awesome. Get cooking!
Oh... I'm so pretentious.

Side note! If you ever turn your camera sideways
to "fit the whole person in"
I’ll kill you and your entire family...
PART FIVE! ORIGINALITY!! AND THE THREE ABILITIES!!!

When it comes to the stuff that’s actually
in your videos there’s a few things you

things that you may want to take into consideration
to stand out and avoid drowning in the endless
sea of people who are way, way cooler than you.

1) Rewatchability! The thing that makes people
want to come back for more and watch your

videos over and over. Keeping the pace snappy
and cutting the unnecessary fat such as title
or credit sequences helps a lot.

2) Quotability! Silly voices and catchphrases
are an upsettingly effective way of getting

yourself stuck in someones head. Also - and
I hate that I’m saying this - but being

relatable and making content relevant to people’s
everyday lives will keep you popping up in
their minds throughout the day.

3) Shareability! Memorable thumbnails, titles
and tags will make your videos easier to find
but I will get onto that in a moment.

Finally - and most importantly - originality
is key. Offering people something new and

exciting will always help. If you’ve watched
enough stuff like I told you to you’ll have

your own style and being "original" won’t
be too hard. What is originality though?

Well in my opinion it’s taking inspiration 
from so many different things that you can

no longer identify one single source. Creativity!
It's basically just a lot of stealing...
(Police Siren)
PART 6! FIRST IMPRESSIONS!!

People say "don’t judge a book by it’s
cover" but they’re still going to. Getting
noticed in the vast terrifying abyss of YouTube is hard enough as it is so it doesn't really hurt to make yourself
stand out. The first impression someone is going to have of your video is going to look a little like this...

In a split second everything from the title,
thumbnail, view count and video length is
going to affect whether or not someone is going to make the decision to watch what you make so...
Make it count!

When it comes to picking a title there’s
plenty of options to choose from:
The Filename, The Descriptive, The Quotation, The Lie, The Clickbait, The Creative and The Gibberish.

Which title should you choose? Well, just
imagine what people are going to be searching for.

Typically it’s either the most memorable
line of the video or a description what actually
happens inside it. You don’t have to name it after those but do make sure you put that stuff in the tags!

As for thumbnails? Well, you’ve got a few
options there too.

The Fortunate, The Unfortunate, The Manufactured
and The Misleading.

A tastefully cropped thumbnail that’s actually
representative of the video itself is usually a safe bet.
Or you could just... Yeah...
PART SEVEN! HERDING!!

It’s all well and good having an awesome
video but once you’ve got someones attention

the mission then becomes keeping it. As I
said before, trimming the unnecessary fat

from a video helps keep folk watching but
once it’s over you get one chance at suggesting

what they do next. So again... Choose wisely.
You can ask them to either:
1) Subscribe and stick around for more (annotation).
2) Watch another video from your channel (annotation).

3) Follow a link in the description to another
website (Twitter, Facebook, etc)

In an ideal world you could ask people to
do all 3 but... People are dumb. So very dumb.
PART EIGHT! MONEY!!!!

Making money off YouTube is entirely optional
but if you’d like to make it your full time

job you’ll need to know how to pay the bills.
There are 3 ways to do this:

1) Advertising! Those ads you see before,
on and around YouTube videos? That’s what

keeps us afloat. A company gives YouTube a
sack of money to display their ads next to

people’s videos and YouTube in turn gives
some of that money to the creators. YAY!

2) Merchandise! Shirts, posters, wristbands
and more. Got a funny catchphrase or a beautiful face?

People are gonna wanna put that on their
bodies. Mmm.

3) Selling out! I mean... Brand sponsorships!
How else are big brands gonna remind people

they exist without paying you to yell about
’em. I myself would never stoop so low.
(Montage)
Side note! Love doin’ that. ’Multi-Channel Networks’ are companies that take care of all the business

stuff and promise to make you more money once
you sign your life away to them. Some are

good, some aren’t so good. Be very careful
before signing any contacts.

Double side note! There’s no quicker way
to screw up your

chances of making a living off YouTube than
infringing copyright. Don’t steal music idiot!
PART NINE! GETTING NOTICED!!!

There are few better ways to grow as a creator
than by collaborating with others.
It’s kinda like... Eating them and stealing their powers. Delicious.

Every skill and resource you lack, someone
else has to offer and vice versa. If you need

music, someone out there will be happy for
the exposure. If you’re a voice actor, someone’s

gonna need your sexy vocal tones. The best
way to break the ice with a creator you want

to work with is to offer them whatever they
lack. Trust me, it works.

A great way to build a relationship with another
creator is to flirt creatively. Covering their

songs, parodying their style, making references
to them in your videos.

Don’t send them naked photos though, that
never ends well. Never.
PART TEN! SURVIVAL!!!

Well, congratulations! You are now equipped
with all the knowledge you need to go forth and...
Waste people’s time.

However, there’s one last thing I need to
tell you before I set you free...

Don’t be a dick. Be kind to your audience because
they’re the ones that ultimately make your

job possible... and be respectful of the other
creators around you because you never know

if you’re going to hurt someones feelings
or make a powerful enemy. There are plenty

of dicks waiting out there to tear you down
for next to no reason. Don’t be one of them.
Good luck, my friends and welcome to YouTube.
TomSka out!
